Reviewed by my 13-year-old son: Do not watch this movie. Although this movie is clearly "Christian", with multiple phrases about prayer and Christ coming to earth as a human, its theology is utterly skewed. (Spoilers) This is a Christmas Carolesque story in which the main character is visited by the ghost of his dead sister in a dream. Throughout the story, many drastic and dangerous theological mistakes are made, like that you must follow your dreams beyond anything else and that good deeds outweigh bad deeds. These misconceptions are presented as important, life-changing truths. In the end, the main character has a drastic change in his life that in a Christian movie you would expect to be repentance and belief in Christ; Actually, it is just that life is worth living and that you should be nice all the time instead of angry all the time. (End spoilers) This movie all around is a poor representation of Christianity and you should watch it with caution if you choose to watch it at all.

Very sweet story of a modern day Scrooge.  As in the traditional Scrooge story, the main character was self centered and mean spirited until events unfolded before him revealing the struggles and heartaches of friends, employees and acquaintances that he had hardened his heart towards.  When he sees the flashbacks and the future events, he has a change of heart and just as the old story goes, he makes amends. A very thought provoking movie.

After watching this movie, I'll never be a Christmas scrooge again!  My birthday is on December 24th, and it's always been hard for me at Christmas, particularly since I grew up in a dysfunctional family, in which Christmas was a time of stress.  This movie inspired me to begin a new way of being at this time of year.  I have decided to be a Christmas angel from now on and give to others.  Watching the main character in the movie going through such a transition is eye opening.  This movie left me with a feeling of joy!

Alright....I'm a little biased because this little film was shot in Jacksonville, OR. , with exteriors of downtown Jacksonville. I have to drive through this charming town every day to go to work in nearby Medford. If any of you readers venture to southern Oregon, Jacksonville is a must see attraction. As for the movie, no it's not the classic "Scrooge" with Alistar Simm, but it is charming in its own right. The evangelical or religious angle is very low key, but it is there, and you know...It's not a bad thing to have. Perhaps the acting or maybe the script could have been tweaked up a notch, but for those of you that can really "suspend your disbelief" and actually get into this film, I think you will agree it is time well spent, and will certainly help to give you a little bit of what Christmas should be.

A modern adaption of A Christmas Carol. Tracks the classic storyline but there are enough differences to keep you engaged.  I especially liked the twist of the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present, and Future being played by a single character - a surprise I won't give away. The Scrooge character is much younger here, and it's a tragedy in his life that makes him so cranky. I actually found his descent a little more believable than the original Scrooge's because it was based on devastating grief. And his reconciliation with friends and coworker at the end is perhaps more downplayed, but more realistic. (You can tell people are going to take a while to believe his transformation, but they they will eventually.) Overall, an interesting work that honors its source material.

This is the only time the weathly want to give a helping hand out of their delusional existance that money will make them happy while trying to compete with the richest, when in reality the middle / lower class families are the ones that strive to make others happy everyday, the people who care, actually care where you feel something inside that makes u want to do more good, they don't need a millionaire to pay for their house or the building they sleep in to stay warm because they'll be by eachothers side no matter what life throws at them........while the weathly stand back and laugh and invest in another business proposition after Christmas holidays... you can have over a billion in your trust fund and watch people struggle and feel good about yourself......what a disgrace to human exsistance, ...this guy in the movie only helped others because he saw himself at the bottom and couldn't image what it would be like to have to work for a meaningful living..........do good because it's the right thing to do, not because someone told you to !

By God's Grace is a modern retelling the story of A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens
minus his animus against Puritans personified by Ebenezer Scourge.
Today's "Scourge" is a young, embittered executive plagued by inexperience that threatens
his suddenly inherited family business.
A juvenile, angelic Grace comes to conduct our modern Scourge through Christmas past, present &  an awful future.
The terrible Christmas future is rendered moot as repentant Scourge breaks free of obsessive bitterness and just in time
to set right his business blunders and celebrate the joy of Christmas present free of poisonous bitterness and resentment.

Charles Dicken's Christmas Carol changed my perception of Christmas at 13 years old.  I am a Christian impart by that story.  It  I gave me a perception of what judgement is in real terms.  Charles Dicken's Christmas Carol defined good from evil in real terms. As a Christian I don't feel required to judge every Christian film as good.  I do not understand why the imagination of J.R.R. Tolkien,  C.S. Lewis, and George MacDonald never find their way to the screen apart from directors like Peter Jackson.  These authors dedicated their lives by unmasking the claims of the Gospel through the imagination.  I can't imagine a non-Christian even staying long enough to see this movie through. My spouse fell a sleep through most of it.  She is a Christian as well.  Drama is often a poor vehicle for evangelism.  It may entertain the Christian but never draws the very people we are trying to reach with the Gospel.

The ghost of his young sister comes to visit him and shows him life is passing him by and how he can be happy again. Will definitely buy this movie.

The protagonist seemed a bit too young to be going through the experience of looking back on all his past actions and future actions that would ultimately give him a change of heart on Christmas Day.  He was anywhere from around age 18 to age 21, I think.

The scenes of a possible future to come were kind of funny in that it seemed to imply that without this one person, who might have just reached the age of drinking, all the people he knew would live ruined lives (or at least, what the movie considers as being a ruined life).  I cannot exactly believe that he had that much impact on those people, but it is enough for him to believe he can make a change, so that's good for the movie.

For these kind of Scrooge stories, It's always fun to see the last few minutes of how the protagonist makes use of his new attitude to the people around him.  I especially liked the way he opened his heart again to his mom's best friend and how he helped the children's home in the movie, including his childhood friends.

Overall, it is a relaxing movie with a known ending, but the interest is in how the movie gets to that ending and what it does in between.

This is a modern-day version of a  "Christmas Carol," with a different twist in that the ghost of Christmas past, present and future is played by the same person.  That person will not be revealed in this review.  Suffice it to say that this film is very heartwarming.

Chris Taylor is the protagonist in this film, and he puts in a fine performance.  And the actress who plays his younger sister, Savannah McReynolds, is excellent.

Watch this film.  It's worth your time.
